overview: Finding a volunteer placement, rights of volunteers, pay, expenses, age limits and claiming benefits while volunteering
title: Volunteering

table.body:
You can search for volunteer placements:

- on the [Do-it](http://www.do-it.org.uk/ "Do-it"){:rel="external"} and [Volunteering England](http://www.volunteering.org.uk/ "Volunteering England"){:rel="external"} websites 
- in your local community through [Community Service Volunteers](http://www.csv.org.uk/?display=volunteering/ "Community Service Volunteers"){:rel="external"} and by checking local noticeboards (eg, in your library) or newspapers 
- on the [VSO](http://www.vso.org.uk/ "VSO"){:rel="external"} website, if you are looking for overseas placements
table.title: Find volunteer placements

table.body:
Most volunteers don’t have a contract of employment, so don’t have the rights of an employee or worker.

You're usually given a volunteer agreement that explains:

+ the level of supervision and support you'll get
+ what training you'll get
+ whether you're covered under the organisation’s employer or public liability insurance
+ health and safety issues
+ any [expenses](pay-and-expenses "Pay and expenses") the organisation will cover

The volunteer agreement isn't compulsory, but sets out what you can expect from the organisation. It doesn’t form a contract between you and the organisation. The National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) has information on [volunteers’ legal status.](http://www.ncvo-vol.org.uk/advice-support/workforce-development/hr-employment-practice/managing-volunteers/legal-status/ "Volunteers’ legal status"){:rel="external"}
table.title: Your rights

table.body:
You won’t be paid for your time. But you may get money to cover expenses. This is usually limited to covering food, drink and travel or any equipment you need to buy. 

If you get any other payment or benefit in kind, you may be classed as an employee or worker, rather than a volunteer. Employees have certain employment rights, like getting the minimum wage.
table.title: Pay and expenses

table.body:
##Age limits

There’s no upper age limit on volunteering. However, some organisations’ insurance policies don’t cover people under 16 or over a certain age (usually 80). 

Under 14s **can't** work for a profit-making organisation, even if they’re not paid.

^Aged 50+? Find volunteering opportunities with the [Retired and Senior Volunteering Programme.](http://www.csv-rsvp.org.uk/site/home.htm "Retired and Senior Volunteering Programme"){:rel="external"}^

##If you're on benefits

You can volunteer and claim benefits if:

+ the only money you get from volunteering is to cover expenses, like travel costs
+ you continue to meet the conditions of the benefit you get

$D
[Download a guide to volunteering while on benefits (PDF, 372KB)](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/docs/dwp1023.pdf "A guide to volunteering while on benefits"){:rel="external"}
$D

##If you've got a criminal record

You may still be able to volunteer. You might need a [criminal records check](/crb-criminal-records-bureau-check "Get a Criminal Records Bureau check") if you want to volunteer with children or vulnerable adults.
table.title: When you can volunteer
